results.snippet: LEAD:  BEAUTIFUL ISLANDS. By Russell Martin. (Linden/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Russell Martin's well-written first novel traces a year in the life of Jack Healy, a decent, fortyish family man whose strenuous career has put too much pressure on his...
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: BEAUTIFUL ISLANDS. By Russell Martin. (Linden/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Russell Martin's well-written first novel traces a year in the life of Jack Healy, a decent, fortyish family man whose strenuous career has put too much pressure on his marriage. This seemingly predictable material is made fresh because Healy is not a typical overworked professional but an astronaut, and because the year revolves around the real-life explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

results.snippet: LEAD:  FESTIVE SUNDAY  From Freeport to Yaphank with a stopover in Huntington, today's the day for Long Island festivals. In Freeport, to celebrate the opening of its new preserve, complete with bird-watching tower and marked trails through the...
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: FESTIVE SUNDAY From Freeport to Yaphank with a stopover in Huntington, today's the day for Long Island festivals. In Freeport, to celebrate the opening of its new preserve, complete with bird-watching tower and marked trails through the marshland, Cow Meadow Park has a Family Nature Festival on tap.

headline.main: Soviet Space Prescription: Artificial Gravity for Long Flights

results.snippet: LEAD: The accumulated experience of Soviet astronauts on long space flights suggests that any manned mission to Mars or beyond should be made in a craft that has a centrifuge to provide artificial gravity, according to the country's top expert on...

byline.original: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The accumulated experience of Soviet astronauts on long space flights suggests that any manned mission to Mars or beyond should be made in a craft that has a centrifuge to provide artificial gravity, according to the country's top expert on space medicine.

headline.main: U.S. Reporters Get Firsthand View of Soviet Space Launching

results.snippet: LEAD: Soviet space officials opened this sensitive launching site to American journalists today in what space experts said was the first visit by reporters from the United States.

byline.original: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Soviet space officials opened this sensitive launching site to American journalists today in what space experts said was the first visit by reporters from the United States.

headline.main: Russia's Ring Of Towns Crowned With Golden Domes

results.snippet: LEAD: AS you approach Suzdal on a sunlit day, one thing stands out from afar: the dome over the entrance gate of the Convent of the Intercession, a lone patch of gold that seems to catch the sunlight and send it, shimmering, into the long, level...

byline.original: By FELICITY BARRINGER; Felicity Barringer is a correspondent in the Moscow bureau of The Times

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: AS you approach Suzdal on a sunlit day, one thing stands out from afar: the dome over the entrance gate of the Convent of the Intercession, a lone patch of gold that seems to catch the sunlight and send it, shimmering, into the long, level distance.

headline.main: Soviet Sets Shuttle For August Launching

results.snippet: LEAD: The Soviet Union's new space shuttle, a reusable craft that lands on a runway, is to make its first voyage at about the same time that the United States space shuttle is scheduled to return to orbit for the first time since the Challenger...
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Soviet Union's new space shuttle, a reusable craft that lands on a runway, is to make its first voyage at about the same time that the United States space shuttle is scheduled to return to orbit for the first time since the Challenger disaster, an industry magazine has reported.

results.snippet: LEAD: CARDIAC INTENSIVE-CARE UNITS ARE paradoxes. They are filled with the tools to delay dying but they keep the language of death at a distance. As an intern, I worked in such a place: a small, brightly lit area, partitioned into eight cubicles and...

byline.original: By DOUGLAS SHENSON, M.D.; Douglas Shenson is a chief resident in social medicine at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: CARDIAC INTENSIVE-CARE UNITS ARE paradoxes. They are filled with the tools to delay dying but they keep the language of death at a distance. As an intern, I worked in such a place: a small, brightly lit area, partitioned into eight cubicles and filled with an overwhelming array of electronic equipment.
